thread.title: San Jose Flooding: 14,000 Told to Evacuate
thread.title_full: San Jose Flooding: 14,000 Told to Evacuate

author: Ted Goldberg
title: San Jose Flooding: 14,000 Told to Evacuate
text:
San Jose city officials have greatly expanded their evacuation orders, prompted by flooding from Coyote Creek, to include around 14 ,000 residents.
“Although the rain has largely stopped, flooding is continuing along Coyote Creek as reservoirs continue to spill and creek flow is extremely high,” said Cherly Wessling, a spokeswoman for the city’s Emergency Operations Center, in an email early Wednesday morning.
The city set up evacuation centers at the Mayfair and Shirakawa community centers, overnight shelters at Evergreen Valley and James Lick high schools and winter warming centers at four library branches.
The flooding has led to more than a dozen road closures.
It arrived on the heels of the latest storm to slam Northern California. The heavy rainfall has filled Anderson Reservoir to capacity, causing water to rush down the dam’s spillway.
Santa Clara Valley water district officials said Wednesday morning that their crews had completed temporary repairs to Coyote Canal work that was aimed at preventing more flooding onto Highway 101.
The expanded evacuation orders came hours after fire crews rushed to rescue hundreds of people in the city’s Rock Springs neighborhood, where homes and cars were inundated under several feet of water.
“I don’t have specific numbers for other water rescue operations, but I can tell you in my career this is probably the biggest,” San Jose Fire Department Captain Mitch Matlow said Tuesday afternoon. “In the history of San Jose, I don’t know if its been bigger, but this is probably in the top 10,” Matlow said.
Andy Seoung was among the residents rescued by fire crews. “At some parts of the street the water is as high as your waist, my waist, “Seoung said. “I’m six feet tall and my waist is about 30 inches off the ground.”
San Jose Mayor Sam Liccardo said Tuesday that officials suspect a breach in the creek caused the rapid flooding in Rock Springs.
“Clearly, there’s a source in the creek where there’s a significantly large amount of water that’s rushing in,” Liccardo said.

KQED’s Peter Jon Shuler contributed to this report.
